tool.name: Paired-end fastq pairer
tool.description: Rewrite paired-end fastq files to make sure that all reads have a mate and to separate out singletons.
tool.command:
## Run fastq_pair fastq_pair
#if $table_size: -t '$table_size' #end if
#if $print_elements: -p '$print_elements' #end if
#if $verbose: '$verbose' #end if
'$fastq1' '$fastq2' &&
#set fq1paired=$fastq1+".paired.fq" #set fq2paired=$fastq2+".paired.fq" #set fq1single=$fastq1+".single.fq" #set fq2single=$fastq2+".single.fq"
mv '$fq1paired' 1.paired.fq && mv '$fq2paired' 2.paired.fq && mv '$fq1single' 1.single.fq && mv '$fq2single' 2.single.fq

param.name: verbose
param.label: Verbose
param.help: Verbose output. This is mainly for debugging.

param.name: fastq1
param.label: FASTQ file 1
param.help: FASTQ file input, file 1 of pair

param.name: fastq2
param.label: FASTQ file 2
param.help: FASTQ file input, file 2 of pair

param.name: print_elements
param.label: Number elements to print
param.help: Print this number of elements in each bucket in the table.

tool.help:
======================================================= Paired-end fastq pairer (fastq_pair) =======================================================
Match up paired end fastq files quickly and efficiently.
fastq_pair [options] [fastq file 1] [fastq file 2]
OPTIONS -t table size (default 100003) -p print the number of elements in each bucket in the table -v verbose output. This is mainly for debugging
